newsitem.title: UK: New UK cabinet agrees legislative programme.
newsitem.headline: New UK cabinet agrees legislative programme.

text.p: Britain's new Labour government on Thursday reached agreement on a crowded legislative programme for its first 1-1/2 years in office, deputy Prime Minister John Prescott said.
"We have agreed the Queen's Speech," he told reporters at the end of the first meeting of Prime Minister Tony Blair's news cabinet.
"It reflects all those priorities that we had in the general election -- that of education, of crime, of jobs, of decentralisation, of devolution," Prescott added.

Earlier, the minister responsible for presentation of government policy said the government would produce a White Paper policy document on freedom of information during the initial parliamentary session, which is expected to last until October 1998.

Peter Mandelson, minister without portfolio, speaking to Channel 4 television, said a Freedom of Information Bill would not be presented to MPs until later in the parliament. "Freedom of Information has not been dropped and it will feature in the Queen's Speech," he said.
Following long-established tradition, Queen Elizabeth will open the new parliamentary session next Wednesday by reading a speech on the government plans, which ministers will have written for her.
